headline: Workday's forecast for quarterly subscription revenue disappoints
summary: Workday raised its annual subscription revenue forecast on Thursday, but an in-line outlook for the current quarter sent the human resources software provider's shares down nearly 4% in extended trading. Workday's customers rely on the company's single cloud-based platform, which provide applications to manage services including recruitment, payroll, accounting and audit. In an uncertain economy, customers are tightening their spending on platforms like Workday as they reassess budgets and timing.

headline: Thoma Bravo Adds Dayforce To Growing Software Portfolio In $12 Billion Deal
summary: Private-equity firm Thoma Bravo agreed to buy Dayforce in a deal valued at $12.3 billion, including debt. Dayforce stock popped earlier this on reports of a deal.

raw.headline: Thoma Bravo Adds Dayforce To Growing Software Portfolio In $12 Billion Deal
raw.summary: Private-equity firm Thoma Bravo agreed to buy Dayforce in a deal valued at $12.3 billion, including debt. Dayforce stock popped earlier this on reports of a deal.

headline: Dayforce Reaches Agreement With Thoma Bravo to Go Private
summary: Dayforce  has reached an agreement to be taken private by the private-equity firm Thoma Bravo in an all-cash deal, the human-resources software company announced Thursday.  Thoma Bravo will pay $70 a share for the company—a 32% premium over the its closing price on Aug. 15, the last day prior to reports about a potential takeover.  The transaction, which is expected to close in early 2026, values  Dayforce  at $12.3 billion.

raw.headline: Dayforce Reaches Agreement With Thoma Bravo to Go Private

The transaction, which is expected to close in early 2026, values  Dayforce  at $12.3 billion.

headline: Thoma Bravo to Buy Dayforce for $11.2 Billion
summary: Dayforce has agreed to be acquired by private-equity firm Thoma Bravo in a deal that values the provider of human-resources software at around $11.2 billion.

raw.headline: Thoma Bravo to Buy Dayforce for $11.2 Billion
raw.summary: Dayforce has agreed to be acquired by private-equity firm Thoma Bravo in a deal that values the provider of human-resources software at around $11.2 billion.

headline: Dayforce to go private in $12.3 billion Thoma Bravo acquisition
summary: (Reuters) -Private equity firm Thoma Bravo has agreed to buy human resources software provider Dayforce for $12.3 billion, including debt, in a take-private deal that executives hope will help expand on the company's AI capabilities.  Dayforce, which operates on a single data platform, uses artificial intelligence to help companies forecast matters such as labor demand or predict employee burnout, David Ossip, the company's CEO, told Reuters in an interview on Thursday, as he elaborated on the deal's benefits.  "Going private gives us more space, flexibility and resources to go much deeper on what matters the most, which is accelerating our focus on being that AI leader in HCM," Ossip said, referring to the practice known as human capital management.

Dayforce, which operates on a single data platform, uses artificial intelligence to help companies forecast matters such as labor demand or predict employee burnout, David Ossip, the company's CEO, told Reuters in an interview on Thursday, as he elaborated on the deal's benefits.  "Going private gives us more space, flexibility and resources to go much deeper on what matters the most, which is accelerating our focus on being that AI leader in HCM," Ossip said, referring to the practice known as human capital management.

headline: Thoma Bravo to buy Dayforce in $12.3 billion deal
summary: Under the terms of the deal, Dayforce shareholders will receive $70 per share in cash, representing an equity value of $11.18 billion, according to Reuters calculations.  Dayforce's stock was up around 2% in early trading after losing about 7% of its value so far this year, underperforming peers.

headline: 1 Cash-Producing Stock with Promising Prospects and 2 We Turn Down
summary: While strong cash flow is a key indicator of stability, it doesn’t always translate to superior returns. Some cash-heavy businesses struggle with inefficient spending, slowing demand, or weak competitive positioning.

headline: Thoma Bravo eyes Dayforce in potential $11bn deal
summary: Dayforce, currently listed on the NYSE and TSX, could become privately-owned if an acquisition deal with Thoma Bravo is finalised.
